p1.title: Population
p1.importance: Total population is a baseline measure that tells us the number of people living in an NPA. It is used to calculate density, and other per capita data. Trends in population show where the community is growing and where it is decreasing, which can help the City and other services providers know where infrastructure and other services may be needed. For additional information, you can click through to find the population breakdown by race and ethnicity, which can also help communities better understand themselves. The 2010 Census reported 308.7 million people in the United States, a 9.7 percent increase from the Census 2000 population of 281.4 million. Overall, the South and West accounted for 84.4 percent of the U.S. population increase from 2000 to 2010.
p1.tech_notes: Summarized the population from the 2010 Census for each NPA using Block Group geography.

p2.title: Median Age of Residents
p2.description: Median age of residents for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
p2.importance: Measuring the average age of a neighborhood’s population provides an indication of its resources and the services it may need.  A neighborhood that is getting older may need services or housing to help residents age in place.  A younger population could need help with educational or employment resources. According to the U.S. 2010 census the median age in North Carolina is 37.4.  The U.S. median age is 37.2.
p2.tech_notes: Averaged the median age from the 2005‐2010 American Community Survey for each NPA using Block Group geography.

p3.title: Area (in acres)
p3.description: Physical size of each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
p3.importance: The size of a NPA is best used to analyze physical characteristics within the neighborhood when measured with population, density, and land use allocation.
p3.tech_notes: ArcGIS (ESRI) calculates the area of each NPA.
p3.links: Future land use plans in Charlotte-Mecklenburg: Charlotte, Davidson, Huntersville, Matthews, Mint Hill, Pineville

p4.title: Percentage of Developed Land
p4.description: Percentage of land built upon for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
p4.importance: Calculating the percentage of developed land is useful when compared to the type and density of uses that exist in a neighborhood for future land use planning.
p4.tech_notes: Percentage land built upon in each NPA divided by the total land area in a NPA.
p4.links: Future land use plans in Charlotte-Mecklenburg: Charlotte, Davidson, http://www.huntersville.org/Departments/Planning.aspx, Matthews, Mint Hill, Pineville

p5.title: Single Family Residential Density
p5.description: Average number of single family dwelling units per acre for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
p5.importance: Calculating single family residential provides an indication of the residential character of a neighborhood.  Lower density single family is typified by larger lots in a suburban development pattern while higher density neighborhoods have smaller lots.  However, residential density is not directly related to house size.
p5.tech_notes: The number of units for each NPA divided by the number of land acres.
p5.links: Future land use plans in Charlotte-Mecklenburg: Charlotte, Davidson, http://www.huntersville.org/Departments/Planning.aspx, Matthews, Mint Hill, Pineville

p6.title: Land Use Proximity
p6.description: The percentage of residents with access to neighborhood serving land uses within ½ mile. (Retail, parks/open space, schools, libraries, activity centers).
p6.importance: National surveys have shown trends in how people choose to live.  An upward trend shows people choosing to live where they have access to basic services such as retail, parks, employment, and educational services. Living close to these types of services can save people money by being located close to compatible uses.  This living pattern also reduces auto useage and negative environmental impacts. However, although a high number of uses reflects greater land use diversity in a specific area, a low number does not  necessarily equate to a less desirable living environment.  Some areas have a low density, rural or suburban character that, in some cases, should remain unchanged.  This development pattern also has environmental benefits which could lead to healthier lifestyles.
p6.links: Future land use plans in Charlotte-Mecklenburg: Charlotte, Davidson, http://www.huntersville.org/Departments/Planning.aspx, Matthews, Mint Hill, Pineville

p7.title: Public Transit Proximity
p7.description: Percent of housing units within a half mile of a transit stop for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA). The average percent for Mecklenburg County is 67%.
p7.importance: Residents in neighborhoods with frequent, easily accessible transit services have the opportunity to use alternate forms of transportation. Benefits of public transportation include reducing the expenses of owning and operating a private vehicle and environment benefits such as improving air quality and reducing congestion.
p7.tech_notes: The number of units within a half‐mail of a transit stop in each NPA divided by the number of housing units in each NPA.
p7.source: Charlotte Area Transit System, Mecklenburg County Tax Parcels
p7.links: Public transportation use, upcoming plans and public meetings, CATS Mobile App for your phone, Getting around in Charlotte-Mecklenburg using public transportation

e1.title: Registered Voters
e1.description: Percent registered voters as of the 2010 election for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
e1.importance: Registering to vote is a fundamental component of community engagement. A low percentage of eligible citizens registered to vote may indicate a need to engage people in the electoral process.  It may also reflect a large percentage of foreign or transient populations.
e1.tech_notes: Number of voters registered in each NPA divided by the population in each NPA.
e1.links: Area election precincts, voting sites, voter registration and other related information, national voting statistics

e2.title: Voter Participation
e2.description: Percentage of registered voter that voted in the 2010 elections for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
e2.importance: Local and statewide elections can have a larger impact on our communities than national elections. In November 2010 (national election) the voter turnout in Mecklenburg County was 37.98% which translates into 228,929 out of 602,710 registered voters who participated.  By comparison, the turnout was 16% in 2009. Tracking NPA’s with low voter participation provides opportunities for officials and residents to implement education and registration activities to increase participation.
e2.tech_notes: Number of voters in the 2010 election for each NPA divided by the registered voter population in each NPA.
e2.links: Area voting sites and voter turnout, national voting statistics

e3.title: Residents Serving on Boards and Committees
e3.description: Total number of residents that serve on appointed public boards, committees and commissions for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
e3.importance: There are a variety of opportunities for residents to be engaged with local government on the City and County level.  Appointees have the ability to make important policy and regulatory decisions that impact neighborhoods. Identifying where appointees are located provides neighborhood leaders, residents and elected officials with information regarding underrepresented areas.
e3.tech_notes: Total number of residents that serve on appointed public boards, committees and commissions including libraries, sheriff and police departments.
e3.source: City of Charlotte, Mecklenburg County, Towns
e3.links: Opportunities for Board and Commission Positions: City of Charlotte, Mecklenburg County

e4.title: 311 Calls for Service
e4.description: Number of non-emergency calls for service for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
e4.importance: The CharMeck 311 system was developed to centralize resident’s calls for the various services provided by the City and County. This is an important piece of information to show the community’s engagement in policing itself.  A higher than average number of calls may be a sign that the neighborhood is improving by correcting issues.  A lower number may reflect better social and economic data, or it could show the lack of engagement by residents if there are incidents that need monitoring and correcting.
e4.tech_notes: Number of non‐emergency calls forservice for each NPA.

e5.title: Registered Neighborhood Organizations
e5.description: Number of neighborhood organizations registered with the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Planning Department.
e5.importance: A key characteristic of community engagement is an active neighborhood organization.  These groups allow residents to discuss issues that are relevant to their area. Identifying registered neighborhood organizations allows city staff to inform leaders about grants and other community building opportunities.
e5.tech_notes: Number of neighborhood organizations registered with the Charlotte‐Mecklenburg Planning Department for each NPA.
e5.links: Neighborhood organization registration process, Funding opportunities for neighborhood organizations, Arts and Science Council, Community Building Initiative

e6.title: Grants Awarded
e6.description: Number of City sponsored matching grants applied for and awarded for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA). Neighborhoods (Neighborhood Matching Grant, Keep Charlotte Beautiful, Neighborhood Energy Challenge, Tree Banding, Tree Banding Grant), Businesses (Business District Organization Program, Façade Improvement program, Security grants, Brownfield grant).
e6.importance: Healthy, vibrant neighborhoods typically have residents that are engaged in the activities that affect where they live. The City’s Neighborhood Matching Grant program awards funds to eligible neighborhood-based organizations for projects that will make neighborhoods better places to live, work, play, and shop. Tracking the number, type and location of neighborhood led projects assists grant providers with outreach and programming strategies.  Additionally, residents are able to monitor the types of projects that were implemented to develop strategic plans for future projects.
e6.tech_notes: Number of matching grants applied for and awarded for each NPA.
e6.links: Funding opportunities for neighborhood organizations, Arts and Science Council, Community Building Initiative

e7.title: Streets Adopted
e7.description: Number of miles of streets adopted for litter cleanup for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
e7.importance: Neighborhoods, businesses and individuals can make a difference in their community by adopting a City street and committing to cleanups once per quarter. Identifying adopted streets provides an indication of the level of involvement residents and businesses have in keeping their neighborhood streets clean and safe.  In areas with no adopted streets residents, businesses and other organizations can develop strategies collaboratively to keep neighborhood streets clean.
e7.tech_notes: Number of miles of streets adopted for litter cleanup for each NPA. Does not include major thoroughfare, private streets, or state maintained roads.
e7.links: Adopt a City Street, Keep Mecklenburg Beautiful, Keep North Carolina Beautiful

m1.title: Median Household Income
m1.description: Median household income of each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
m1.importance: The median household income provides an indication of how well people are doing financially in a neighborhood.   Income is related to disposable income and saving.  Lower wage earners may have higher percentages of their income devoted to critical needs and less for saving.  Higher wage earners may have more savings that can enable them to be more resilient in economic downturns and more of their income available for consumption. Total disposable income is a function of both consumption and population. Service providers and retailers look at income levels to help them locate their services. According to the Census Bureau the federal poverty threshold for a family of four was $22,350 in the lower 48 states and the median household income in North Carolina for a family of four was $65,036.
m1.tech_notes: The median household income for each neighborhood profile area. The amount is inflation adjusted for 2010.
m1.links: Charlotte Works, Goodwill, Jacob’s Ladder, North Carolina Employment Security Commission, NC Joblink, Self Help, United Way, Urban League of Central Carolinas, Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services, Median incomes in surrounding North Carolina counties

m2.title: Persons Employed 6 Months or Less
m2.description: Percent of Work Force Age 16‐64 working less than 26 weeks in the past year.
m2.importance: Information on unemployment is not available at the neighborhood level.  Therefore, we are using Percentage of Employed 6 Month or Less in combination with Percentage of Persons Working 35 Hours or Less  as proxies to examine under and un employment in our community. Measured in conjunction with the Percentage of Persons Working 35 Hours or Less provides a more complete picture of how people are working. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the unemployment rate in North Carolina declined from 11.4% in January 2010 to 10.6% in December 2010.
m2.tech_notes: The sum of work force working less than 26 weeks divided by the work force who worked any time within the last 12 months. N/A includes NPAs with zero work force age population.
m2.links: Charlotte Works, Goodwill, Jacob’s Ladder, North Carolina Employment Security Commission, NC Joblink, Self Help, United Way, Urban League of Central Carolinas, Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services, Starting a business, Small Business Administration, Business licenses and permitting, Entrepreneurship and the U.S. economy

m3.title: Persons Working 35 Hours or Less
m3.description: Percentage of persons not working full time for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
m3.importance: Information on the unemployment rate is not available at the neighborhood level.  Therefore, we are using Percentage of Persons Employed 6 Month or Less in combination with Percentage of Persons Working 35 Hours or Less a week as proxies to examine under and un employment in our community. Recent changes in the economy have negatively impacted families across the country.   Analyzing the strength of our workforce through persons not working full time provides an indication of a community’s economic stability. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the unemployment rate in North Carolina declined from 11.4% in January 2010 to 10.6% in December 2010.  This equates to 490,460 unemployed North Carolinians at the end of the year 2010.
m3.tech_notes: The sum of work force working less than 35 hours and 50 weeks of the year divided by the working age population (ages 16‐64).  Does not include number of jobs.
m3.links: Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services, Charlotte Works, Goodwill, Jacob’s Ladder, Self Help, United Way, Starting a business, Small Business Administration, Business licenses and permitting, Entrepreneurship and the U.S. economy

m4.title: Population Receiving Food and Nutrition Servces (FNS)
m4.description: The percentage of population receiving Food and Nutrition Services (FNS) for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
m4.importance: The Food and Nutrition Services (FNS)  is established to end hunger and improve the health of low-income people by helping families buy the food they need for a nutritionally adequate diet. Increasing numbers of FNS recipients signifies changes in household incomes.  Identifying the locations of this trend can be useful for service providers for improving access to healthcare providers, full service grocers and other supportive uses. According to the Food Research and Action Center, the number of FNS recipients in North Carolina increased 18.9% from 2009 to 2010.  By December 2010 the total number of residents was 1,547,621.
m4.source: Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services as of August 2011.
m4.tech_notes: The total population receiving Food and Nutrition Services (FNS) for a NPA divided the total population for a NPA.   Areas with less than 5 FNS recipients has been suppressed.
m4.links: Applying for Food and Nutrition Services, Care Ring, CW Williams Community Health Center, Free or low cost clinics

m5.title: Change in Single Family Property Value
m5.description: Percent change in single family property value for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
m5.importance: Measuring the rate of change in property value indicates the level of stability. Higher values may be perceived as being a positive trend based on new amenities in the area and other factors.  Neighborhoods with below average housing values may increase in value at a faster rate than other neighborhoods. Between 2008 and 2010, property values in North Carolina declined approximately $2,000 overall according to the Zillow Home Value Index.
m5.source: Mecklenburg County Tax Parcels from 2003 to 2011
m5.tech_notes: The change in total assessed value for single family attached and detached housing units from 2003 to 2011 divided by the total assessed value for single family attached and detached housing units from 2003 was averaged for each NPA. NPAs with less than 5 qualifying properties were classified as N/A. The average change in house value per year was 0.8% in Mecklenburg County.
m5.links: North Carolina housing statistics, Mecklenburg County real estate database, Am I eligible for tax relief on my home?, Mecklenburg County property revaluation process

m6.title: Square Feet of Commercial Buildings
m6.description: The total square footage of developed commercial space zoned for said use which includes business, office, industrial and institutional uses, not including religious institutions and schools.
m6.importance: Calculating the total amount of commercial space, when compared to the amount of vacant space, provides a method to determine if there is an oversupply of commercial space.

m7.title: Permitted New and Renovated Commercial Buildings
m7.description: The total square footage of new and renovated (complete upfits) commercial buildings for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
m7.importance: Determining the amount of new and renovated commercial space in a neighborhood is an indicator of where economic activity is occurring in our community. Similar to capturing the number of total square feet available, a neighborhood may not be able to absorb additional commercial development based on zoning, infrastructure, future land use plans, or demographics.
m7.tech_notes: The total heated square feet of permitted new and renovated Commercial Buildings each NPA using US Department of Commerce reporting data on New and Alterations to Buildings (Codes 213,318‐320,322‐328). There are 8.4 million square feet represented on this map.
m7.links: Apply for a building permit, Commercial plan review process, City of Charlotte financial programs, GeoPortal, Virtual Charlotte, Polaris

m8.title: Non-Residential Building Code Violations
m8.description: Number of non‐residential code violations for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
m8.importance: Mecklenburg County’s building code regulations are in place to ensure the public is protected from the effects of sub-standard building conditions.  Structures that do not meet minimum standards must achieve compliance through the code process. A high number of violations may indicate targeted areas for improvement or the presence of older buildings in need of rehabilitation.
m8.source: Neighborhood and Business Services and  Mecklenburg County Code Enforcement
m8.links: Apply for a building permit, Commercial plan review process, City of Charlotte financial programs

m9.title: Average Year of Construction of Commercial Buildings
m9.description: Average age of commercial buildings for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
m9.importance: Older buildings are often obsolete and need help to be reused.   Ageing commercial structures may provide opportunities for rehabilitation and reuse, particularly big box retail and older commercial strip centers.  Knowing the age of building helps the City and County determine where to target incentives and inspections.
m9.source: Mecklenburg County Tax Parcels as of October 2011
m9.tech_notes: Average year of construction for commercial buildings for each Neighborhood Profile Area.
m9.links: Apply for a building permit, Commercial plan review process, City of Charlotte financial programs

m10.title: Change in Non-Residential Property Value
m10.description: Change in non-residential property value from year to year for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
m10.importance: Measuring the rate of change in property value indicates the stability, rate of increase or rate of decrease in a neighborhood’s non-residential building stock. It is also a measure of desirability in terms of running a successful business in relation to the supply and cost of available sites. Increasing values may indicate limited supply of commercial space, improving employment opportunities, higher median incomes and other economic indicators. Decreases in value may indicate an oversupply in commercial space or, competition from newer commercial space in the area.

s1.title: Violent Crime Rate
s1.description: Violent crimes in 2011 as defined by the North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation including Murder, Rape, and Aggravated Assault that were identifiable to a Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
s1.importance: This data shows us where we have high rates of crime and enables neighborhoods to see how they compare to others.  By disaggregating the data by types of crimes, residents and police departments can develop strategies to target specific crimes. Crime rates that are above the city and county averages should also be evaluated with other variables such as land use, code violations, and property ownership to reveal patterns and causes of certain types of crimes.
s1.source: Data provided by Charlotte-Mecklenburg, Pineville, Cornelius, and Huntersville Police Departments
s1.tech_notes: The total number of violent crime in each Neighborhood Profile Area as described were divided by the population for each Neighborhood Profile Area. The per person rate was converted to number of crimes per 100,000.
s1.links: Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department Violent Crimes Division, Crime prevention and safety best practices, How to start a neighborhood crime watch, Cornelius Police Department, Davidson Police Department, Huntersville Police Department, Matthews Police Department, Mint Hill Police Department, Pineville Police Department

s2.title: Property Crime Rate
s2.description: Property crimes in 2011 as defined by the North Carolina Bureau of Investigation included Burglary, Larceny, and Motor Vehicle Theft that were identifiable to a Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
s2.importance: This data shows neighborhoods with high incidences of property crime, and enables neighborhoods to see how they compare to others.  By disaggregating the data by types of crimes, residents and police departments can develop strategies to target specific crimes. Crime rates that are above the city and county averages should also be evaluated with other variables such as land use, code violations, and property ownership to reveal patterns and causes of certain types of crimes.
s2.tech_notes: The total number of property crimes in each NPA as described were divided by the population for each NPA. The rate was converted to number of crimes per 100,000.
s2.links: Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department Property Crimes Division, Crime Prevention through Environmental Design (CPTED), Crime prevention and safety best practices, How to start a neighborhood crime watch, City of Charlotte security grant program, Cornelius Police Department, Davidson Police Department, Huntersville Police Department, Matthews Police Department, Mint Hill Police Department, Pineville Police Department

s3.title: Juvenile Incident Rate
s3.description: The rate of arrests related toincidents committed by children under the age of 16 in 2011for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
s3.importance: Tracking juvenile crime rate shows where the crimes were located and not where children live who commit the crimes.   This enables communities to focus on the location of juvenile crimes.  Such crimes are often committed near schools and malls. Reporting the data more accurately allows police departments, school officials, residents, community relations agencies, and area businesses develop strategies to reduce the number of juvenile crimes.
s3.source: Data provided by Charlotte‐Mecklenburg, Pineville, and Huntersville Police Departments
s3.tech_notes: The total number of incidents committed resulting in an arrest of children under the age of 16 were divided by the juvenile population for each Neighborhood Profile Area.
s3.links: Charlotte Mecklenburg Police Department gang prevention programs, Charlotte Mecklenburg School System Police Department, Juvenile and victim mediation services, Mecklenburg County Juvenile Crime Prevention Council, City of Charlotte youth service initiatives

s4.title: Fire Calls for Service Rate
s4.description: The fire calls for service rate for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
s4.importance: Fire departments are often the first responders to certain types of accidents as their role goes beyond fire safety.  By tracking the number of calls for the various services they provide, public safety officials, residents and businesses can develop strategies for targeted solutions.  In addition, calls for service increase municipal operating costs.  Therefore, reducing calls can save the tax payer money.
s4.source: Data provided by Charlotte Fire Department and Mecklenburg E911
s4.tech_notes: The number of fire calls for service foreach NPA divided by the NPA population. Fire calls for serviceincluded but were not limited tostructure fires, vehicle fires, and fire alarms for both residential and nonresidential structures. Motor vehicle fires were included but accidents were excluded. Any calls for service wherethe primary reason was medic related were not provided.
s4.links: Charlotte Fire Department, Charlotte Fire Department station locations, Area resources for emergency housing or financial assistance, Cornelius-Lemley Fire Department, Davidson Fire Department , Huntersville Fire Department, Matthews Fire Department, Mint Hill Volunteer Fire Department, Pineville-Morrow Fire Department

s5.title: Calls for Animal Control Rate
s5.description: Rate of calls for animal control.
s5.importance: The CharMeck 311 system was developed to centralize resident’s calls for the various services provided by the City and County. Higher than average calls for animal control could signify issues with property ownership, a growing wildlife population, or a lack of education regarding responsible pet ownership.  Significant animal control issues and pet overpopulation create unsafe environments for residents and strains animal shelters and their resources.
s5.tech_notes: The number of animal control calls divided by the NPA population.

k1.title: Number of Pre-School Programs
k1.description: Number of licensed childcare facilities for ages 0-5 including Center Based and Family Care for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k1.importance: Tracking the number and location of pre-school programs allows residents to identify service gaps in their neighborhoods.  A low number of programs may assist education providers determine where and how to implement services based on related variables such as population age, population density, household income data and other education data such as EOC and EOG scores. By disaggregating the data based on state regulated Star ratings, an analysis can be determined on the quality of registered pre-school programs.
k1.tech_notes: Number of licensed childcare facilities for ages 0‐5 including Center Based and Family Care for each NPA.
k1.links: Mecklenburg County preschool programs, The Children’s Alliance out of school programs and partners, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas, North Carolina Division of Child Development and Early Education

k2.title: Number of School Aged Programs
k2.description: Number of licensed school aged (5-12) programs for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k2.importance: Tracking the number and location of after school time programs allows residents to identify service gaps in their neighborhoods. A low number of programs may assist education providers determine where and how to implement services based on related variables such as population age, population density, household income data and other education data such as EOC and EOG scores. According to an Education Week report, after-school programs are often seen as an effective way to keep children safe and supervised. Experts also believe that the after-school hours are an opportunity to further engage students in academic, social, and physical activities. As former U.S. Secretary of Education Richard W. Riley noted, Children's minds don't close down at 3 p.m.
k2.tech_notes: Number of licensed school aged (5-12) programs measured as a raw number for each NPA.
k2.links: North Carolina Division of Child Development and Early Education, After school computer literacy and technology programs, Programs offered by Big Brothers, Big Sisters, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas, http://www.thechildrensalliance.org/resources/where-to-find-help.html, The Children’s Alliance out of school programs and partners, Education Week report on the benefits of after-school education programs

k3.title: 3-5 Graders who were Proficient in End of Grade (EOG) Tests
k3.description: Percent of students proficient in End of Grade testing for CMS students in grades 3-5 for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k3.importance: Averaging test scores in a neighborhood assists education administrators, businesses, and residents develop strategies for improving academic performance where needed.  Tracking the data over time also provides a trend analysis for preventing continued decline in education indicators. Measuring the improvement of schools with increasing scores allows administrators and residents to discuss best practices in public education that could be used in other areas. Related variables to academic performance are education attainment of parents, economics, health indicators and the proximity neighborhood supporting land uses.
k3.tech_notes: The total number of students passing both reading and math end of grade tests divided by the total number of students taking both reading and math end of grade tests.
k3.links: The North Carolina End-of-Grade Tests, North Carolina End-of-Course Tests, Education support for homeless children and families, City of Charlotte youth service initiatives, After school computer literacy and technology programs, Help your child succeed with ‘Parent University’, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas

k4.title: 6-8 Graders who were Proficient in End of Grade (EOG) Tests
k4.description: Percentage of students meeting expected growth goals in End of Grade testing for CMS students in grades 6-8 for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k4.importance: Averaging test scores in a neighborhood assists education administrators, businesses, and residents develop strategies for improving academic performance where needed.  Tracking the data over time also provides a trend analysis for preventing continued decline in education indicators. Measuring the improvement of schools with increasing scores allows administrators and residents to discuss best practices in public education that could be used in other areas. Related variables to academic performance are education attainment of parents, economics, health indicators and the proximity neighborhood supporting land uses.
k4.tech_notes: The total number of students passing both reading and math end of grade tests divided by the total number of students taking both reading and math end of grade tests.
k4.links: The North Carolina End-of-Grade Tests, North Carolina End-of-Course Tests, Education support for homeless children and families, City of Charlotte youth service initiatives, After school computer literacy and technology programs, Help your child succeed with ‘Parent University’, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas

k5.title: 9-12 Graders who were Proficient in End of Grade (EOG) Tests
k5.description: Percentage of students meeting expected growth goals in End of Grade testing for CMS students in grades 9-12 for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k5.importance: Averaging test scores in a neighborhood assists education administrators, businesses, and residents develop strategies for improving academic performance where needed.  Tracking the data over time also provides a trend analysis for preventing continued decline in education indicators. Measuring the improvement of schools with increasing scores allows administrators and residents to discuss best practices in public education that could be used in other areas. Related variables to academic performance are education attainment of parents, economics, health indicators and the proximity neighborhood supporting land uses.
k5.tech_notes: The total number of students passing both reading and math end of grade tests divided by the total number of students taking both reading and math end of grade tests.
k5.links: The North Carolina End-of-Grade Tests, North Carolina End-of-Course Tests, Education support for homeless children and families, City of Charlotte youth service initiatives, After school computer literacy and technology programs, Help your child succeed with ‘Parent University’, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas

k6.title: 3-5 Graders with End of Grade (EOG) Test Score Growth
k6.description: Percentage of students showing growth in End of Grade testing for CMS students in grades 3-5 for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k6.importance: Averaging test scores in a neighborhood assists education administrators, businesses, and residents develop strategies for improving academic performance where needed.  Tracking the data over time also provides a trend analysis for preventing continued decline in education indicators. Measuring the improvement of schools with increasing scores allows administrators and residents to discuss best practices in public education that could be used in other areas. Related variables to academic performance are education attainment of parents, economics, health indicators and the proximity neighborhood supporting land uses.
k6.tech_notes: The total number of students with an end of grade test growth value in reading and math with an average greater than zero divided by the total number of students with end of grade growth values.
k6.links: The North Carolina End-of-Grade Tests, North Carolina End-of-Course Tests, Education support for homeless children and families, City of Charlotte youth service initiatives, After school computer literacy and technology programs, Help your child succeed with ‘Parent University’, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas

k7.title: 6-8 Graders with End of Grade (EOG) Test Score Growth
k7.description: Percentage of students showing growth in End of Grade testing for CMS students in grades 6-8 for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k7.importance: Averaging test scores in a neighborhood assists education administrators, businesses, and residents develop strategies for improving academic performance where needed.  Tracking the data over time also provides a trend analysis for preventing continued decline in education indicators. Measuring the improvement of schools with increasing scores allows administrators and residents to discuss best practices in public education that could be used in other areas. Related variables to academic performance are education attainment of parents, economics, health indicators and the proximity neighborhood supporting land uses.
k7.tech_notes: The total number of students with an end of grade test growth value in reading and math with an average greater than zero divided by the total number of students with end of grade growth values.
k7.links: The North Carolina End-of-Grade Tests, North Carolina End-of-Course Tests, Education support for homeless children and families, City of Charlotte youth service initiatives, After school computer literacy and technology programs, Help your child succeed with ‘Parent University’, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas

k8.title: 9-12 Graders with End of Grade (EOG) Test Score Growth
k8.description: Percentage of students showing growth in End of Grade testing for CMS students in grades 9-12 for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k8.importance: Averaging test scores in a neighborhood assists education administrators, businesses, and residents develop strategies for improving academic performance where needed.  Tracking the data over time also provides a trend analysis for preventing continued decline in education indicators. Measuring the improvement of schools with increasing scores allows administrators and residents to discuss best practices in public education that could be used in other areas. Related variables to academic performance are education attainment of parents, economics, health indicators and the proximity neighborhood supporting land uses.
k8.tech_notes: The total number of students with an end of grade test growth value in reading and math with an average greater than zero divided by the total number of students with end of grade growth values.
k8.links: The North Carolina End-of-Grade Tests, North Carolina End-of-Course Tests, Education support for homeless children and families, City of Charlotte youth service initiatives, After school computer literacy and technology programs, Help your child succeed with ‘Parent University’, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas

k9.title: Students with 10 or more Unexcused Absences
k9.description: Percentage of students with 10 or more excused or unexcused absences shown as a percentage compared to the CMS average for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k9.tech_notes: The total number of students with 2 or more end of course tests and passed them all divided by the total number of students with 2 or more end of course tests. NPAs with less than 5 students were suppressed.

k10.title: Dropout Rate
k10.description: Percentage of students that drop out of high school compared to the CMS average for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k10.importance: Dropping out of high school significantly reduces the likelihood finding steady employment with reasonable wages.  Studies have consistently shown that the higher level of educational attainment, the greater the chance of earning higher wages and staying employed. Neighborhoods with a population of students who do not finish school may reflect other negative trends such as higher crime, lower median incomes, lower property values and conditions, and higher health disparities. By identifying neighborhoods with high dropout rates, administrators are able to leverage resources from education support agencies, police departments, community leaders, and other partners to implement strategies that will reduce dropout rates.
k10.tech_notes: The total number of Charlotte Mecklenburg School (CMS) students who withdrew (CODE W2A) from CMS divided by the total number of 9‐12 grade students NPAs with less than 5 students were suppressed. This map illustrates 1,116 CMS dropouts representing 2.9% of students.
k10.links: Parent University, Urban Youth Empowerment Program, Resources for improving student performance, North Carolina End-of-Grade Tests, North Carolina End-of-Course Tests, ACE Mentor Program, North Carolina Mentoring Partnership, A Child's Place, Mayor's Youth Employment Program, Mayr's Mentoring Alliance, Communities in Schools, Council for Children's Rights, Gang Prevention, Florence Crittenton Services, United Family Services, Teen Health Connection, Services for at-risk teenagers, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas, Who drops out of school, and why?

k11.title: Percent without High School Diploma
k11.description: Percent without High School Diploma for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k11.importance: Nationwide studies have historically shown a correlation between educational attainment and improving one’s quality of living.  Other studies have analyzed the benefits to tax payers with a population that attains a higher level of education. Measuring educational attainment can reveal opportunities for directing education or employment resources to areas with a low number of adults with college degrees and high dropout rates. According to American Community Survey, the nation’s unemployment rate for adults with a Bachelor’s degree was 4.9%, while the average for adults with a high school diploma was 9.4% and 14.9% for adults without a diploma in 2011.
k11.tech_notes: The number of people 25 or older with less than a high school diploma for each NPA divided by the number of people 25 or older for each NPA.  N/A includes only NPA’s with zero people 25 and older.
k11.links: Obtaining a GED, Fill My Cup, Jacob's Ladder, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas, U.S. Bureau of Labor education statistics, A Stronger Nation Through Higher Education, North Carolina Educational attainment - percent high school graduate or higher, Educational Attainment by State, Educational Attainment by Degree-Level and Age-Group, Benefits of education

k12.title: Children Attending Private Schools
k12.description: Percent of Children Attending Private Schools for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
k12.importance: Tracking home schooled children reflects emerging trends of how parents choose to educate their children. According to the National Center for Education Statistics, the number of homeschooled students was about 1.5 million, an increase from 850,000 in 1999 and 1.1 million in 2003. The percentage of the school-age population that was homeschooled increased from 1.7 percent in 1999 to 2.9 percent in 2007.
k12.tech_notes: The number of children attending private school divided by the number of children enrolled in school.
k12.links: State requirements for home schooling, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools services for home schooled children and parents, After school computer literacy and technology programs, Fast Facts - Homeschooling, Home Schooling in the United States

h1.title: Juvenile Population Receiving North Carolina State Children’s Health Choice
h1.description: Percent of Juvenile Population Receiving North Carolina Health Choice for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
h1.importance: The program has been successful in improving access to health care for low-income children. Parents reported that the program helped make health services financially accessible to their children, enabling them to get needed physician's care, eyeglasses, or prescription drugs. According to the North Carolina Institute of Medicine, there were 1,046,396 children insured through public health insurance programs in 2010, a 24% increase from 2005.
h1.source: Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services
h1.tech_notes: The total population receiving North Carolina Health Choice (NCHC) for a NPA divided the total juvenile population for a NPA. Areas with less than 5 NCHC recipients have been suppressed. This map illustrates 11,554 participants representing 5.0% of the juvenile population.
h1.links: NC Department of Health and Human Services, Ada Jenkins Center, Care Ring, C.W. Williams Community Health Center, Charlotte Community Health Clinic, Childcare Resources, NC MedAssist, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas, Mecklenburg County resource portal for Latino populations, North Carolina Child Health Report Card

h2.title: Births to Adolescents
h2.description: Percentage of births to females under age 19 divided by the total number of births for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
h2.importance: Research shows that teenage pregnancy is associated with increased risk of poor social, economic and health outcomes for both mother and child. High rates of births to adolescents may influence trends in education variables (dropout rates, absences) and reflect accessibility issues with health education and health providers (location and affordability) as well as a number of other socioeconomic factors. According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, North Carolina was ranked 34 out of 51 states and the District of Columbia on 2010 preliminary teen birth rates among females aged 15-19 (with 1 representing the lowest rate and 51 representing the highest rate).  On a similar scale – where 1 is the lowest teen pregnancy rate and 51 is the highest – North Carolina was ranked 37 out of 51 states and the District of Columbia in pregnancies to females aged 15- 19 in 2005.
h2.tech_notes: Number of births to adolescent in 2009 and 20010 divided by all births for each NPA in 2009 and 2010. NPAs with less than 5 births were not shaded. Mecklenburg County Average: 4.75%
h2.links: NC Department of Health and Human Services, Florence Crittenton Services of North Carolina, Levine Children’s Hospital, United Family Services, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas, Health statistics, surveys and publications for North Carolina, Mecklenburg County resource portal for Latino populations

h3.title: Population Receiving Medicaid
h3.description: Percent of individuals that receive Medicaid for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
h3.importance: Medicaid is a proxy measure for poverty. High or increasing numbers of Medicaid recipients may be connected to other issues such as access to healthcare providers and usually reflects high unemployment or policy changes which expand eligibility. According to the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services, a total of 1,726,412 individuals were eligible for Medicaid in 2008, approximately 19% of the state’s population.
h3.source: Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services
h3.tech_notes: The total population receiving Medicaid for a NPA divided the total population for each NPA.
h3.links: Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services, Ada Jenkins Center, Care Ring, C.W. Williams Community Health Center, Charlotte Community Health Clinic, NC MedAssist, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas, Mecklenburg County resource portal for Latino populations

h4.title: Age of Death
h4.description: The average age of death for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
h4.importance: Calculating the average age of death is a valuable data point to determine social or environmental issues in a neighborhood. A low average may indicate a variety of issues including health behaviors (physical activity, nutrition, tobacco and alcohol use and, high risk activities), health access, environmental health, safety issues related to infrastructure conditions, and land use compatibility issues.
h4.tech_notes: The average age of death for each NPA.
h4.links: The Arc Of Mecklenburg County, United Family Services, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas, Charlotte Department of Transportation, NC Department of Health and Human Services, Mecklenburg County resource portal for Latino populations

h5.title: Residents within ½ Mile of Medicaid Provider or Free Clinic
h5.description: Percent within ½ Mile of Medicaid Provider or Free Clinic. Medicaid providers include primary care, OB/GYN, internal medicine, and pediatrics and free health clinics for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
h5.importance: This variable looks at the location of all healthcare providers within a neighborhood.  It does not take into account whether these providers have restrictions on who they care for.  It is a way to analyze potential gaps in areas that may need certain types of health services.  Therefore, this data should be used in comparison with median income, population demographics and other data. Many providers do not accept Medicaid. Free clinics and providers who offer low flat fee services are scattered throughout the county and may not be open every day. Physical barriers may include a lack of public transit options, poor street design, substandard ADA infrastructure, inferior pedestrian amenities (sidewalks, lighting, crosswalks), or other accessibility issues.
h5.source: Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services
h5.tech_notes: The number of housing units with ½ mile of a Medicaid provider or free clinic in a Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA) divided by the number of all housing units in an NPA.
h5.links: Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services, Ada Jenkins Center, Care Ring, C.W. Williams Community Health Center, Charlotte Community Health Clinic, NC MedAssist, Agencies supported by United Way of Central Carolinas, Mecklenburg County resource portal for Latino populations

h6.title: Residents within ½ Mile of a Chain Grocery Store
h6.description: Percentage of population within ½ mile of a chain grocery store for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
h6.importance: Chain groceries are one measure of access to healthy foods as they offer fresh meat, dairy and produce in one location. National studies report the presence of affordable fresh food in a community has the potential to improve residents’ nutrition and overall health. Additionally, attracting full-service grocery stores can boost the local economy – grocery retail creates jobs, generates tax revenue, draws foot traffic to support neighboring businesses, and helps spur other development.
h6.tech_notes: The number of housing units with ½ mile of a chain grocery story in a NPA divided by the number of all housing units in a NPA. Does not include non-full service stores (e.g. convenience stores), farmer’s markets or food delivery services.
h6.links: Mecklenburg County Food and Nutrition Services Program, Charlotte Green, City of Charlotte, Mecklenburg County Park and Recreation, UNCC food service assessment report, Mecklenburg County resource portal for Latino populations

h7.title: Residents within ½ Mile of Public Outdoor Recreation Area
h7.description: Percent of housing units with a 1/2 mile of a public outdoor recreational area for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).  Uses include parks, greenways, recreations centers and boat landings.
h7.importance: Recreational facilities provide opportunities for physical activity and social interaction, both key components of good physical and mental health. According to a survey of residents conducted by Mecklenburg County Park and Recreation, 74% ranked walking and bike trails as the top recreation priority for neighborhoods followed by district parks, nature centers, neighborhood parks, and park shelters with picnic areas. Studies have also shown that open space in urban areas has the potential to increase the level of economic benefits to surrounding property owners.
h7.tech_notes: The number of housing units with ½ mile of a public outdoor recreation area in a NPA divided by the number of all housing units in an NPA. Recreation areas include those maintained by Mecklenburg County Parks and Recreation and Charlotte Mecklenburg Schools.
h7.links: Mecklenburg County Park and Recreation Master Plan, YMCA of Greater Charlotte, YWCA of Greater Charlotte, Mecklenburg County resource portal for Latino populations

g1.title: Housing Units
g1.description: Total number of single and multi-family dwelling units for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g1.importance: The total number of housing units is a profile variable that identifies the number and types of residential units in a neighborhood.  The data can be used to determine potential areas for residential and non-residential development.
g1.tech_notes: The number of housing units identified as residential summarized for each NPA.
g1.links: Builders of Hope, Charlotte Housing Authority, Charlotte Mecklenburg Housing Partnership, Habitat for Humanity, Self Help Credit Union, City of Charlotte housing services, Façade grants for apartment complexes, Security grants for apartment complexes

g2.title: Vacant Single Family Parcels
g2.description: Number of vacant parcels zoned for single‐family detached housing. There were on average 47 vacant parcels zoned for single family detached for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g2.importance: Identifying vacant single family parcels provides information for new housing opportunities.  The data also provides guidance for land use planning, identifying land use conflicts (vacant residential land adjacent to heavy industrial, for example), or identifying land for conservation.
g2.tech_notes: The total number of vacant parcels zoned single family.
g2.links: Charlotte, Davidson, Huntersville, Matthews, Mint Hill, Pineville, Purchasing real estate owned by the City of Charlotte

g3.title: Average Year of Single Family Construction
g3.description: Average year built of residential dwellings for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g3.importance: The average year of housing construction provides an indication of the condition of a neighborhood’s housing stock.  Typically, older houses need some level of repair, renovation, or maintenance. Comparing the average year of construction with other variables such as housing code violations provides an indication of areas in need of home improvement resources.
g3.tech_notes: Average year of construction for single family detached housing for each Neighborhood Profile Area. N/A includes NPAs with zero residential buildings.
g3.links: Builders of Hope, Habitat for Humanity, Love-INC., City of Charlotte Housing Services, Local historic districts, Local historic landmarks

g4.title: Heated Square Feet of Single Family Detached Dwellings
g4.description: Average size of single family detached dwellings based on heated square footage in a Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g4.importance: Calculating the average dwelling size can be useful to assess the impact of house size on the environment and maintenance costs.  Possible impacts include household energy consumption, lot coverage, tree canopy coverage, and storm water system impacts. The data may also reveal trends of how people are choosing to live, relative to recent changes in the economy.  Recent national studies have shown a slight reduction in the size of new single family homes due to changes in income or a desire to reduce energy consumption and other maintenance costs.
g4.tech_notes: The average heated square feet of all single family detached housing for each Neighborhood Profile Area.
g4.links: Builders of Hope, Habitat for Humanity, Love-INC., City of Charlotte Housing Services

g5.title: Number of new residential building permits in a Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g5.description: Tracking permit data for new residential construction provides an indication of market conditions, the availability of developable land, or trends in how people choose to live (single family vs. multi- family housing). Related variables that identify trends in the housing market include average size of single family dwellings, median income, non-residential development, renovation permits, and change in property value.
g5.importance: Calculating the average dwelling size can be useful to assess the impact of house size on the environment and maintenance costs.  Possible impacts include household energy consumption, lot coverage, tree canopy coverage, and storm water system impacts. The data may also reveal trends of how people are choosing to live, relative to recent changes in the economy.  Recent national studies have shown a slight reduction in the size of new single family homes due to changes in income or a desire to reduce energy consumption and other maintenance costs.
g5.tech_notes: The number of residential building permits summarized for each NPA (New) using US Department of Commerce reporting data on New Buildings (Codes 100 through 105). There are 4,192 new residential building permits represented on this map.
g5.links: Builders of Hope, Charlotte Housing Authority, Charlotte Mecklenburg Housing Partnership, Habitat for Humanity, Self Help Credit Union, City of Charlotte housing services

g6.title: Residential Building Permits (Renovation)
g6.description: Number of renovation permits for residential buildings for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g6.importance: The number of residential building permits summarized for each NPA (Renovation) using US Department of Commerce reporting data on Alterations to Buildings (Codes 434 and 438).
g6.tech_notes: The number of residential building permits summarized for each NPA (New) using US Department of Commerce reporting data on New Buildings (Codes 100 through 105). There are 4,192 new residential building permits represented on this map.
g6.links: Builders of Hope, Habitat for Humanity, Love-INC., City of Charlotte Housing Services, How to apply for a building permit

g7.title: Single Family Property Value
g7.description: Average tax value of single family dwellings, condominiums and townhomes for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g7.importance: The total assessed value for single family dwellings, condominiums, and townhomes was averaged for each NPA.
g7.tech_notes: The total assessed value for single family dwellings, condominiums, and townhomes was averaged for each NPA.
g7.links: Mecklenburg County property revaluation process, Am I eligible for tax relief on my home?, Mecklenburg County real estate database, North Carolina housing statistics

g8.title: Change in Single Family Property Value
g8.description: Percent change in single family property value for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g8.importance: Calculating the rate of change in property value indicates the level of stability. Increasing values may be perceived as being a positive trend based on new amenities in the area and other factors. However, neighborhoods with below average housing values have the potential to increase in value at a faster rate than other neighborhoods. Between 2008 and 2010, property values in North Carolina declined approximately $2,000 overall according to the Zillow Home Value Index.
g8.tech_notes: The change in total assessed value for single family attached and detached housing units from 2003 to 2011 divided by the total assessed value for single family attached and detached housing units from 2003 was averaged for each NPA. NPAs with less than 5 qualifying properties were classified as N/A.
g8.links: Mecklenburg County property revaluation process, Am I eligible for tax relief on my home?, Mecklenburg County real estate database, North Carolina housing statistics

g9.title: Foreclosures
g9.description: Percentage of foreclosures for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g9.importance: The foreclosure crisis can have debilitating effects on neighborhoods.  Concentrations of foreclosed homes in an area negatively affect property values and public services. Foreclosures can be found in all neighborhoods; however, the impacts are more problematic in certain locations and within certain housing markets.
g9.tech_notes: The number of foreclosures for single family (attached and detached) in each NPA identified by the Sales Code of FC in Sale History divided by the number of single family (attached and detached) in each NPA. There are 3,520 foreclosures represented on this map or 1.2% of single family (attached and detached) housing units.
g9.links: City of Charlotte Housing Services, Charlotte Family Housing, Charlotte Men’s Shelter, Hope Haven, Self Help Credit Union, YWCA

g10.title: Vacancy Rate
g10.description: The rate of vacancies of residential dwelling units for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g10.importance: Vacant units are an occurrence in all areas.  Long standing and concentrated amounts of vacant properties are an indication of issues such as financial stress on the owner, less than standard housing conditions, housing design or oversupply.
g10.tech_notes: The number of housing units vacant for each NPA divided by the number of housing units for each NPA.

g11.title: Single Family Rental Dwellings (Detached)
g11.description: Percentage of detached single family rental dwellings for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g11.importance: Homeownership is not a realistic or desirable option for many residents, particularly in the current economic climate. There is no reliable data regarding the effect of rented homes on neighborhood property value.  Increasing numbers of rented properties should be analyzed with other data such as the age and condition of the homes, design, or house size, adjacent land uses, and area incomes. A major factor to consider with rented property is the level of management by the owners which impacts adjacent properties positively or negatively as much as owner-occupied dwellings.
g11.tech_notes: The number of single family (detached) rental housing was summarized for each NPA and divided by the NPA total number of single family (detached housing).
g11.links: Municipal residential zoning code enforcement information, City of Charlotte Housing Services, Builders of Hope, Charlotte Housing Authority, Charlotte Mecklenburg Housing Partnership, Self Help Credit Union

g12.title: Subsidized Housing Units
g12.description: Percent subsidized housing units for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g12.importance: Identifying the location of subsidized units allows housing providers to develop implementation plans based on local and federal housing policies.  It also allows residents understand the types of housing choices that are present in their community. According to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, concentrating assisted-housing for low and very low income Americans in dense, urban areas is not an effective use of scarce affordable housing resources. Mixed-income development, which may include units for lower income residents, has become a popular housing solution by creating diverse communities and decentralizing poverty.
g12.source: Charlotte‐Housing Authority, Housing and Urban Development, Charlotte‐Mecklenburg Housing Partnership, Habitat for Humanity
g12.tech_notes: The number of subsidized housing for each neighborhood Profile Area is divided by the total number of housing units for each neighborhood Profile Area. Subsidized housing includes both single family (detached and attached) and multi-family housing. The data provided for NPAs within the City of Charlotte include but are not limited to subsidized units that are defined in the Housing Locational Policy. Although most subsidized housing units are multi‐family, the data and information available to distinguish between the two housing types is not reliable. The definition of subsidized housing varies depending on the municipality.
g12.links: Builders of Hope, Charlotte Housing Authority, Charlotte Mecklenburg Housing Partnership, Habitat for Humanity, Self Help Credit Union, City of Charlotte Housing Services Housing programs and services, City of Charlotte’s Housing Locational Policy

g13.title: Gross Rent
g13.description: Median gross rent of residential dwellings for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g13.importance: Quantifying housing affordability by median rental cost provides an indication of the overall value of residential property, amenities in the surrounding area or types of adjacent land uses among other related variables. Neighborhoods with rental costs below area averages do not always indicate a lower quality of living.  Other factors to consider in lower rents are the average size of housing units, location, housing design, and supply of housing in the area.
g13.tech_notes: The median gross rent for each NPA.  Gross rent is the contract rent plus the estimated average monthly cost of utilities (electricity, gas, and water and sewer) and fuels (oil, coal, kerosene, wood, etc.) if these are paid by the renter (or paid for the renter by someone else). The median gross rent for Mecklenburg County is $829. N/A includes only NPAs with less than 50 rental units. Rent cost is inflation adjusted to 2010.
g13.links: Builders of Hope, Charlotte Housing Authority, Charlotte Mecklenburg Housing Partnership, Habitat for Humanity, Self Help Credit Union, City of Charlotte housing services, YWCA, Hope Haven, Charlotte Men’s Shelter

g14.title: Housing Code Violations
g14.description: Percentage of units with housing code violations in a neighborhood.
g14.importance: Mecklenburg County’s housing code regulations are used to ensure residents are not affected by substandard residential buildings.  Structures that do not meet minimum housing code must achieve compliance through the housing code process. A high number of violations may indicate targeted areas for improvement or the presence of older buildings in need of rehabilitation.
g14.source: Neighborhood and Business Services and Mecklenburg County Code Enforcement
g14.tech_notes: Shown as an average compared to total number of dwellings in the NPA.
g14.links: Municipal residential zoning code enforcement information, City of Charlotte Housing Services, Builders of Hope, Habitat for Humanity, Love-INC., City of Charlotte Housing Services, How to apply for a building permit

g15.title: Neighborhood Nuisance Violations
g15.description: Number of calls for nuisances for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g15.importance: The City of Charlotte's Health and Sanitation Ordinance requires property owners to maintain their premises in a safe and sanitary condition.  Violations include high weeds/grass, accumulation of trash or junk, and junk automobiles. Tracking the types of calls assists neighborhood residents identify repeated problems and develop a strategy to identify solutions.  Sudden increases in nuisance calls for service may also show signs of improvement in a community through focused enforcement efforts.
g15.source: Neighborhood and Business Services and Mecklenburg County Code Enforcement

g16.title: Residential Zoning Violations
g16.description: Number of zoning code violations for each Neighborhood Profile Area (NPA).
g16.importance: Zoning code violations are improper uses of a structure based on the zoning district regulations, such as an auto repair business operating in a residential zoning district.   Zoning violation data provides information on the effectiveness of enforcement regulations. Sudden increases in violations may show signs of improvement in a community through focused enforcement efforts.
g16.source: Neighborhood and Business Services and Mecklenburg County Code Enforcement
g16.links: Zoning code, City of Charlotte rezoning process, Davidson, Huntersville, Matthews, Mint Hill, Pineville, GeoPortal, Virtual Charlotte, POLARIS

w1.title: Commuters Driving Alone
w1.description: Percentage of participants 16 years or older who commute to work by driving alone.
w1.importance: Transportation alternatives offer mobility options for residents of all ages and income levels and can help bridge the spatial divide between people and jobs, services, and training opportunities.
w1.tech_notes: Data derived from the American Community Survey and only measures mode of transit from home to work.

w2.title: Length of Commute
w2.description: Percentage of commuters 16 years of age or older whose length of commute is within the prescribed interval of time in minutes.
w2.importance: Lengthy commutes contribute to increased fossil fuel consumption and congestion.  Significant use of fossil fuels increases costs and contributes to diminished air quality.
w2.tech_notes: Data derived from the American Community Survey and only measures length of  commute from home to work (one way). Data is reported in increments of less than 10 minutes, 10-19 minutes, 20-29 minutes, 30-39 minutes, 40-59 minutes, 60-89 minutes and greater than 90 minutes. The average length of commute for Mecklenburg County is 20-29 minutes.

w3.title: Daily Transit Boardings
w3.description: The average number of daily users boarding public transit within Neighborhood Profile Area.  Includes bus and light-rail users.
w3.importance: Determines a baseline for evaluating the number of residents utilizing public transit for weekday trips. This baseline can be used to determine whether ridership is increasing or decreasing over time.
w3.tech_notes: Derived by averaging the total number of boardings occurring at all stops within the NPA over the course of the current year divided by the number of days in a year.

w4.title: Bicycle Master Plan Implementation
w4.description: Percentage of bicycle infrastructure improvements that have been installed versus the total number of planned bicycle infrastructure improvements per the adopted Charlotte Bicycle Master Plan.  Improvements may include bicycle lanes, signed routes, paved shoulders and/or bike racks.
w4.importance: In September 2008 The City of Charlotte adopted the Charlotte Bicycle Master Plan.  The plan recognizes that cycling has positive transportation, environmental, economic and health benefits and provides a framework for installation of bicycle infrastructure (bicycle lanes, signed routes, paved shoulders and/or bike racks) within the city limits.
w4.tech_notes: Unmarked off-street and unpaved bicycle paths are not included. Data does not take into account any physical obstructions that would prevent or impair an individual’s ability to access the location or amenity. The quality of the bike lane is not assessed.

w5.title: Paved Streets with Sidewalks
w5.description: Percentage of paved streets that have sidewalks on at least one side of the street.  Sidewalks not adjacent to public streets and unpaved walking trails are not included.  The quality of the sidewalk is also not assessed.
w5.importance: Adequate sidewalk systems encourage pedestrian connectivity  which provides mobility options for residents of all ages and incomes.  Identifies NPA's where additional sidewalks may be needed.
w5.tech_notes: Calculated by dividing the length of paved street with sidewalk on at least one side divided by the total length of paved streets.  Sidewalks not adjacent to public streets and unpaved walking trails are not included.  Data does not take into account any physical obstructions that would prevent or impair an individual’s ability to access the location or amenity. The quality of the sidewalk is also not assessed.

w6.title: Street Connectivity Index
w6.description: Ratio of links to nodes within the street network.
w6.importance: The City of Charlotte requires internal and external street connectivity by ordinance.  Connectivity facilitates vehicular, bicycle and pedestrian transportation options.
w6.tech_notes: Represents the total number of street links (roadways or pathways) divided by the number of nodes (cul-de-sac or endpoint).  Data does not take into account bicycle lanes, sidewalks, trails or other transportation modes which may increase or decrease connectivity options within the NPA.

w7.title: Impervious Surface
w7.description: Percentage of impervious surface coverage in relation to total area of the NPA.  Does not take into account whether the NPA is urban, suburban or rural.
w7.importance: Impervious surface is a standard profile variable that allows the City to evaluate the amount of increase or decrease over time. This profile should be evaluated in conjunction with the density score of an NPA.
w7.source: Mecklenburg County Land Use & Environmental Services
w7.tech_notes: The total acres classified as impervious surface using digital orthophotos provided by Mecklenburg County LUESA divided by the total acreage in the NPA.

w8.title: Structures in Floodplain
w8.description: Number of structures within the floodplain along FEMA regulated streams.  Does not include areas subject to flooding that are not regulated by FEMA.
w8.importance: Defines the number of structures likely to experience flooding over time and can assist in prioritizing what areas may be beneficial for participation in FEMA sponsored buyout programs.
w8.tech_notes: The total number of structures that fall partially or completely within the FEMA designated floodplain.  Does  not include areas subject to flooding that are not regulated by FEMA.

w9.title: Tree Canopy
w9.description: Percentage of total area covered by tree canopy.  Includes residential and non residential areas.
w9.importance: Reflects the amount of tree cover within an NPA and establishes a baseline for achieving the City of Charlotte's Tree Canopy Goal of 50% in 2050.
w9.tech_notes: Charlotte Solid Waste Services (CSWS) collects these data.  UNC Charlotte and CSWS staff have begun conversations regarding the best methodology for representing this variable.

w10.title: Total Waste Generation
w10.description: Neighborhood’s total waste generation per capita including solid waste and recycling waste.
w10.importance: Profile variable that reflects the total waste generation per NPA including recycled and non-recycled solid waste.
w10.source: Mecklenburg County Land Use & Environmental Services
w10.tech_notes: Tree canopy coverage will be calculated using aerial photography.  Commercial, industrial, residential, institutional and open space areas will be included in the percentage.

w11.title: Homes Participating in the Residential Recycling Program
w11.description: Percentage of eligible residences within the NPA who participate in the City sponsored residential recycling program.
w11.importance: This information could help to identify areas where resident education programs are needed  or routes could be adjusted.
w11.tech_notes: Determined by data from sensors affixed to residential roll out bins.  Recycling participation is determined by dividing the number of collections in a month by the total possible collections for the month aggregated for each NPA. Only includes data for single family residential units (attached and detached) and multi-family residences with less than 25 units and any additional legacy multi-family dwellings.  Does not include information from all apartment complexes.

w12.title: Tonnage of Recycled Waste
w12.description: Tonnage of residential recycled waste per capita.  Does not include recycled waste for multi-family or non-residential structures.
w12.importance: Reflects the amount of recycled waste per capita.  This information provides a baseline for evaluating percent change and the effectiveness of available programs to increase recycling.
w12.tech_notes: Tonnage of recycled waste per capita, estimated from collections per route divided by number of persons per capita as determined by the most recent decennial census.  Does not include recycled waste for multi-family or non-residential structures.

w13.title: Tonnage of Solid Waste (non-recycled)
w13.description: Tonnage of residential solid waste per capita.
w13.importance: Reflects the amount of recycled waste per capita.  This information provides a baseline for evaluating percent change and the effectiveness of available waste reduction programs.
w13.tech_notes: Methodology is still under development.  Tonnage of solid waste per capita estimated from collections per route divided by number of persons per capita as determined by the most recent decennial census. Does not include recycled waste for multi-family or non-residential structures.

w14.title: Water Consumption
w14.description: Reflects amount of water being consumed per capita within the NPA.  This information could help in identifying areas where resident education programs could be beneficial.
w14.importance: Reflects the amount of recycled waste per capita.  This information provides a baseline for evaluating percent change and the effectiveness of available waste reduction programs.
w14.tech_notes: The number of residential accounts and their total CCF were summarized for each NPA. The total CCF was divided by the number of accounts to obtain the average residential CCFs.  Does not include multi-family structures utilizing a single meter, homes on well water or non-residential structures.

w15.title: Adopt-a-Stream Participation
w15.description: Percentage of existing streams within the NPA that are maintained by Adopt-a-Stream Program.  Only includes NPA's that contain eligible streams.
w15.importance: Provides baseline information regarding  neighborhood interest & willingness to participate in programs with positive environmental impacts.   Identifies neighborhoods where increased program education may be needed.
w15.tech_notes: The length of stream banks maintained by the adopt-a-stream program divided by the total length of stream banks in each NPA. Does not include shoreline along the Catawba river.  For areas where a stream forms the NPA boundary, the linear feet of adopted area will be equally attributed to both NPA's.

w17.title: Residential Electricity Consumption
w17.description: Average annual electricity consumption in kilowatts per NPA.
w17.importance: Provides baseline information to determine the average electricity use for households within the NPA.  Data can been used to target educational programs, weatherization services, grant funds or other initiatives to reduce energy use in areas that exhibit higher usage.  Reducing electricity use saves money and lowers the demand for additional power plants to be constructed which may lead to increased air pollution and degradation of resources.
w17.tech_notes: Data includes information aggregated at the zip code + 4 scale of geography.  Data is not included for cases where the zip code +4 sample is fewer than 5 customers.  Specific customer information,  such as names, addresses, and account numbers will not be disclosed or included.  Data represents the average energy use in kilowatts for the 12-month period beginning January 1, 2011 and ending December 31, 2011.

w16.title: Residential Natural Gas Consumption
w16.description: Average annual natural gas consumption in therms per NPA.
w16.importance: Provides baseline information to determine the average natural gas use for households within the NPA.  Data can been used to target educational programs, weatherization services, grant funds or other initiatives to reduce natural gas use in areas that exhibit higher usage.  Reducing natural gas use saves money and decreases the need for additional wells and pipelines which may contribute to degradation of resources.
w16.tech_notes: Data includes information aggregated at the zip code + 4 scale of geography.  Data is not included for cases where the zip code +4 sample is fewer than 5 customers.  Specific customer information,  such as names, addresses, and account numbers will not be disclosed or included.  Data represents the average energy use in kilowatts for the 12-month period beginning January 1, 2011 and ending December 31, 2011.
